sect1.title: CASE 26
sect1.para: Authors’ note: These two brief cases illustrate infections with two different types of organisms associated with the small risk of eating raw or undercooked fish, a popular protein source in much of the world.

The patient was a 15-year-old boy who presented to his local pediatrician with acute onset of rectal pain. On the morning of his presentation, he noticed that he passed what he described as a yellow “string” of about 4 feet in length in his stool. This “string” was not associated with either blood or pus. Residual “string” was stuck in his anus, and when the patient tried to pull it, it caused severe lower left quadrant abdominal pain. With his mother out of the room, the patient denied ingesting anything unusual and adamantly denied inserting anything in his anus or any kind of sexual contact.

On physical examination, vital signs were within normal limits. An anal examination revealed the presence of a 50-cm-long rubbery, segmented string extruding from his anus. The patient reported pain when the object was pulled. It was extracted from the anus and sent for microbiologic examination, the results of which are seen in Fig. 26.1 and 26.2.

sect1.para: When the laboratory identified the organism, the father said the patient had recently returned from a wilderness trip in northern Ontario. His son had proudly told him that he had caught a northern pike, cleaned it himself, and then cooked it over an open fire.

Name two fish that are commonly associated with infection with this organism. What can be done to prevent the organism from being transmitted when any of the above foods are ingested?

sect2.para: The second case is of a 52-year-old immigrant from South Korea who had a 10-year history of sporadic abdominal pain typically after eating spicy food. However, over the past few months she had had an unintentional 10-lb weight loss. Otherwise, her physical and laboratory findings were unremarkable. However, she did have a family history of stomach cancer. A gastric biopsy was performed with the results seen in Fig. 26.3.

sect2.para: On pathology, there was no evidence of malignancy or dysplasia, but the pathologist reported that there was a submucosal necrotizing granulomatous response to nematode larvae.

sect2.para: 1. The organism extracted from the patient’s anus was a flat, wide, segmented worm most consistent with a tapeworm. In addition, the segments of the worm were quite wide, which makes this most consistent with the tapeworm Dibothriocephalus latus (1). Latus is the Latin word for “broad” or “wide.”

2. The structure of a tapeworm is simple, with a head, the scolex, attached to many segments that appear rectangular, called proglottids. Proglottids contain both sexual organs and are egg-producing machines making hundreds of thousands of eggs per worm per day (2). This tapeworm species grows rapidly in humans and may grow by more than a meter in a week. Worms can grow to be as long as 15 meters in the human intestine, but most are much shorter than that (2). The segments may also break off and be passed, appearing like rice grains in feces. The segment that was crushed was a proglottid. When a gravid proglottid is crushed, eggs are released. The size (45 by 65 μm) and shape of the egg seen in Fig. 26.2 are consistent with D. latus. A key feature of the eggs of this worm is the operculum, which is difficult to appreciate in Fig. 26.2. The operculum is on the end of the egg and is the site where the initial larval stage emerges from the egg.
3. Yes, he likely did not cook the fish thoroughly and became infected with the larval form of D. latus present in the fish flesh. It was unknown if anyone else shared the fish with him.

4. Humans are the definitive host for D. latus, which means a human is the host in which parasite reproduction occurs (2). The life cycle of D. latus is complex (see Fig. 26.4). Eggs are produced and fertilized in the proglottids. These eggs are released from the worm and passed in feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and the larvae are ingested by copepods (small crustaceans), which are the first intermediate host of this parasite. In the crustaceans, the parasite develops into a stage called the procercoid. When the infected crustacean is ingested by a freshwater or anadromous fish, the procercoid enters the tissue of the fish and develops into the plerocercoid phase. This phase, when ingested by humans in uncooked or undercooked fish flesh, develops into the adult tapeworm, where the cycle can begin again.

There are two other tapeworms that are common in humans: the pig tapeworm,Taenia solium, and the bovine tapeworm, Taenia saginata (3, 4). Humans can be both the definitive and intermediate host for T. solium but only the definitive host for T. saginata (3). The determining factor in whether humans are an intermediate or definitive host for T. solium is the stage of the ingested parasite. If eggs excreted by humans are ingested, the patient is an intermediate host, and the disease process that develops is called cysticercosis (3). If T. solium cysts are ingested by eating raw or undercooked pork, then the individual is the definitive host, and an adult tapeworm results. The common parlance for all three tapeworms depends upon the name of the intermediate host from which the human host becomes infected.

sect2.para: 5. All these forms of fish are eaten uncooked, which allows the plerocercoid larval stage to survive and infect the human. The larval stage can be killed in one of two ways (5). One is by cooking it to 55 °C for 5 minutes; the other is to freeze the fish at –20 °C for 1 week or –35 °C for 1 day. Unfortunately, most individuals who eat sushi, sashimi, or other types of raw fish prefer the texture of unfrozen fish.

Many freshwater lake fish have been found to be infected with this parasite, including pike, perch, burbot, and walleye(5). In certain European locales, as many as 15% of the lake fish are infected with this organism. D. latus is also common in anadromous fish, which are fish that swim upriver in order to spawn in freshwater (5). The key anadromous fish that are infected with D. latus and can cause human infection are the different species of salmon. Both trout and whitefish also can be a source of this infection.

6. Most individuals do not realize they are infected with D. latum unless they see passed proglottids in the feces. In this case, the individual likely had the worm in his large bowel, which explained the pain he felt when the physician tried to extract the worm. A single dose of praziquantel is sufficient to purge the worm (5). Most patients are asymptomatic, but those with a high worm burden may experience gastrointestinal symptoms, including diarrhea, abdominal pain, and discomfort. Probably the most severe complication of D. latus infection in patients with a high worm burden is pernicious anemia. Anemia is a result of a parasite-induced vitamin B12 deficiency. It is estimated that the worms absorb 100 times more B12 than the host, and if the worm burden is high enough, this can result in B12 deficiency (5).

listitem.para: 7. The nematode larvae that are most likely to be found in the stomach of humans are those from Anisakis sp. (6). Humans are an accidental host of this parasite, meaning the life cycle of this nematode cannot be completed in humans; they are “dead end” hosts. Definitive hosts are marine mammals. Anisakis is also called “whale worm” because whales are one of its definitive hosts.

8. Larval forms of this worm can be found in a wide array of fish, primarily those found in cold waters in the Northern Hemisphere. People become infected by ingesting a larval form of the worm in the flesh of raw or pickled fish or squid. The highest number of cases of Anisakis infections occur in Japan, South Korea, and Spain (7). Anisakis cases are much less common than those due to D. latus (7). A food history was not obtained from the patient, but it seems likely that she was infected at some point when she was visiting family in South Korea and ate tainted raw fish or squid.

9. The combination of abdominal pain, recent unintentional weight loss, a family history of stomach cancer, and female sex in a South Korean increased the likelihood of gastric cancer in this individual. As a result, a gastric biopsy was performed to rule out gastric cancer. The absence of dysplasia and malignancy was reassuring. Globally, South Korea, along with Japan, has one of the highest prevalences of gastric cancer (8). What is unusual about the South Korean population is that women have a higher rate of gastric cancer, while in other areas of the world this cancer is more frequent in men (8).

sect2.para: The clinical case was unusual for an Anisakis. This infection typically has an acute onset with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, which typically resolves in less than a week (6). In some patients, abdominal pain may be chronic, but a history of 10 years of abdominal pain is unusual (7).

listitem.para: 10. Single larvae are typically seen on endoscopy, and the treatment is to remove them (7). Two of the three larvae were surgically removed. Albendazole has been used empirically, but the efficacy, dosage, and length of treatment have not been established (6).

11. As with D. latus, cooking fish or squid at 55 °C for 5 minutes or freezing it at –20 °C for 1 week or –35 °C for 1 day is protective. Because the larvae are visible in the fish flesh, they can be removed, and the fish can be safely consumed. The flesh should not be consumed if it is heavily infested with larvae. Marine fish flesh frequently contains Anisakis larvae (6). Individuals consuming sushi or sashimi should eat these only if the fish has either been frozen or prepared by experienced sushi chefs who recognize and can safely remove larvae.
Eating raw seafood comes with risks of becoming infected with larvae of both cestodes (tapeworms) and nematodes (roundworms).

The most common tapeworm that infects humans after ingesting the flesh of infected freshwater fish or fish that spawn in freshwater (commonly salmon) isD. latus. This cestode can complete its life cycle in humans. Importantly, the tapeworm can be identified based on the morphology of the eggs it produces in the host’s feces.
The most common nematode that infects humans after ingesting infected fish or squid is Anisakis species. The larval form can attach to a variety of tissues, but most commonly attaches to the stomach.

Neither parasite typically causes severe clinical disease, although defecating a large segment of a tapeworm certainly would be distressing, while severe abdominal pain is reported with acute Anisakis infections.
One dose of praziquantel is sufficient to purge D. latus. Anisakis is typically treated by removing the larvae during endoscopy. Albendazole has been used to treat this infection.
Infection prevention is the same for both worms: thoroughly cooking fish and seafood (55 °C for 5 minutes) or freezing it at –20 °C for 1 week or –35 °C for 1 day.
